d: Issue of marriage of brother and sister of highest chiefly rank is a god.
Special place where occur births of royalty.
Prophecy that brother who first kisses saint will be king.
Choice of kings by divine will.
r: *Egerton JAOS XXXIII 158; Krappe Revue Hispanique LVI (1922) 5 24; *Penzer V 175ff.; *Chauvin VI 75 No. 239; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Winner of contest to be king.
King chosen by contest: princes finding greatest fault with their father.
a: Youngest can find no fault and is chosen.

d: The one of two giant brothers who performs the greatest feat and procures the wildest dog elected as king.
The one of two giant brothers who gets the most skillful princess elected as king.
Owner of magic object chosen as king.
King chosen on basis of strength and exploits.
r: Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: He who can open palace door to be king.
Amasser of largest fortune to be king.
He who can fill out a certain wide seat chosen as king.
Inauguration of king as espousal to goddess.

r: Penzer II 127; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys.

a: Attackers flee into exile.

d: Good king never retreats in battle.
Dead king carried into battle in his war-chariot.
King in battle hides in ditch, with earth piled around him.
Just king brings good fortune upon people.
Four duties of king to subjects: devotion, protection of subjects, justice, and increase of his kingdom.
Clever king knows everything in advance.
King banishes nobleman whose castle he wants.
Nobility of character a mark of kings.
a: Kings overcomes passion for beautiful captives and sends them back untouched to their people.

d: King is superior to all in strength, beauty, largeness, etc., and usually has victory.
King to be seen after anger cools.
Mismanagement of king's treasury a mortal offense.
Royal purple (golden diadem) worn as sign of royalty.
Kingly insignia worn only on field of battle.
Ring can make or unmake a king.
Custom to appoint a king by day and slay him at night.
King must never be present at funeral.
King has first choice in booty.
Fifth of the land's production belongs to king.
Prisoners released as celebration of king's success.
King will not permit a one-eyed man in his presence.
King playing chess when important news arrives.
King orders all gold brought to him.
King never touches earth: carried always by slaves.

a: He sulks here until his wishes are carried out.

d: None permitted to enter hall of king unless he possesses an art.
King does not want men who are unable to engage in any sport.
King asks all newcomers what they can do and expects a prompt answer.
Law that nobody may give the king bad tidings.
King angry at hero who rides straight into the castle without permission.
King has his own gifts stolen back for him.
King gives his own wife as reward.
King requires everyone who comes before him to tell a story.
King has champion to enforce respect.
Threefold division of king's day:  one third dedicated to watching boys at play; one third to playing fidehell (chess?)
a: ; one third to drinking.

d: King orders man whose neck the rope will fit to be executed.
King goes in disguise at night to observe his subjects.
Tom-tom beater to spread the news of kingship.
King shows himself in public only one day a year.
King keeps lions as pets and a lion-tamer at his palace.
King does not eat much during years of famine in order not to forget the hungry.

a: Beaten because he does not get up early enough. (King Alfred and the cakes.)

d: Disguised king taught courtesy by peasant.
r: English: Wells 94 (The Taill of Rauf Coilyear).

d: King pardons person who has made mistake of addressing one of his courtiers as king.
King demands subject's wife for himself.
King carries off subject's wife and makes her his own.
King loses his kingdom to impostor.
King is cursed by disguised dwarf-smiths whose work he criticised.
King frees man sent by rival king to kill him.
a: He sees bravery in the would-be assassin.

d: King descends to bottom of sea in glass barrel to study ways of fishes.
King himself works at brick building so that subjects cannot complain of enforced labor.
Subjects drive their ruler away after he has made them do forced labor.
King (prince) retires from the world (becomes hermit, swineherd).
r: *Chauvin VI 194 No. 363; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.

d: King on retiring orders funeral obsequies given him.
King learning of queen's adultery abdicates.
The higher the office held in this world, the heavier the judgment of God: Cuchulinn's reason for abjuring kingship.
Father abdicates in favor of son.
King must resign if he begets natural son.
Attempt to kill old king by suffocating him in bathroom.
King too old to fight goes himself into his grave mound.

r: *Wesselski Mdrchen 230; Icelandic: Corpus Poeticum Boreale I 303, *Boberg.
*Penzer IV 255 ff., 264; **Zachariae Zs. f. Vksk. Icelandic: *Boberg; Slavic: Mbchal 233; India: *Thompson-Balys; Melanesia: Codrington 288ff.; Africa: Frobenius Atlantis VII 106, 227.
a: Wife burned with dead king.

d: Shavings of spear which killed king cast into cataract.
King slain by "his own household" in revenge for deposing his father.
Land where every raja dies; if he rules for a day he dies that night; if he rules for a night, he dies that day.
No sons left to rule after father.
a: Lawmaker's sons slain in rebellion against him.

d: At son's wedding king names him as successor.
Vengeance for destruction of fairy-mound pursues king's descendants.
First man to arrive after king's death to be heir.
r: (Cf. +N683.) Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 605a n. 62; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Queen chosen to live rather than king so that she can bear an heir to the throne.
a: Serpents alleged to tell by their death which shall die first: male serpent predicts king's death; female, queen's. King has male serpent killed.

d: Second-born son declared as successor because message about the birth of first son was slower traveling.
a: Emperor will not change proclamation.

d: Succession will fall to line that has been wronged.

r: (Cf. +P17.10.) Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: Neuman.

d: Natural son succeeds to the throne.
Natural son is refused kingship and half heritage.
Three sons each get a kingship, but the youngest the most important in the home country.
Slayer of king marries widow and inherits kingdom.
King to be succeeded by whoever can carry his dead body a certain distance.
What the princes most desire: king asks each of three sons separately.
a: Answers: to study, to make pilgrimages, to build a great kingdom. Last chosen.

d: After highly mourned wife's death the king marries another who turns out to be an evil witch.
Limited number of wives for polygamous king.
King's presence necessary for army's victory.
King may have any woman as paramour if he makes her a settlement.
King abducts woman to be his paramour.
King must procure whatever visiting poets ask, or suffer from their satire.
King may judge against all save one of highest rank in religion or learning.

r: Greek: Odyssey VI 313; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Queen marries murderer of her fiancie.
Queen leaves country with her son, having killed her husband in revenge for his killing of her father and brother.
Queen persuades king to make war without cause that her sons may have territory.
Queen persuades husband to riot against his superior.
Queen persuades husband to claim her father's kingdom after his death.
Queen persuades husband to avenge her father.
Queen offers son to be killed in order to spur to fight and avenge her first husband.
Queen must pay tribute to victorious queen to the amount paid by king to victorious king.
Queen commits suicide, as her husband vanquishes and kills her father and her brother.
King sits mourning on his wife's grave mound.
King mourns so much at wife's death that he goes on piracy, (every summer afterward).
King calls daughter in second marriage by the name of his first queen.
Chieftainess of such rank that none of her countrymen can woo her.
No king to rule who is not husband of certain queen.
Queen commits adultery with husband's foster son.
Queen (princess) pours liquor for battle champions.
All children born in realm on same day as chief's son are brought to palace to be the boy's companions.
Prince imprisoned as hostage for safety from king.
Unknown prince chosen chief of children in play.
Dispossessed prince taunted by usurper's son.
Birth rites confer royalty on infant prince.
Prince forfeits father's and God's blessing if he fails to claim throne.
Princess cannot be married to someone of low caste, though he passes suitor test.
Great warrior destroyed by king when he asks for princess in marriage.
King and vassals: obligations of vassals to king.
King demands open gate to vassals' castle (city).
Earl's name preferred to king's.  Icelandic: Boberg.
Noble person saves self from difficulties by knowledge of a trade.
Knight's duty to perform as lady bids.
Noble woman given to foreigners on condition that thereafter their land be held by female right.
Certain foods, ornaments, feathers, etc. reserved for royalty.
Garment must be removed in presence of certain high chiefs.
Impossible to refuse the request of a troubled nobleman.
Banished minister found indispensable and recalled.
Minister acts as stepping-stone in midst of flame-filled trench so that king can step across from one side to the other.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Man so rich that people prefer the dung from his mules over king's gold and silver.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire; Jewish: Neuman.

d: Beggar rewarded by king for poem (song).
Female slaves as medium of exchange (unit of value).
Branding person makes him one's slave for life.
Bond woman with rope girding her loins.
Requirement that slaves given as tribute should not know Irish.
Captives from battle sold as slaves.
Futile attempt to get rid of man by selling him to merchants as slave.
Children of slave and free person become slaves.
Knocking out a slave's tooth entitles him to freedom.
Fool makes friends with birds and beasts.
Customary to shave heads of demented so that they may be recognized as such.
Fool recognized by lump on his forehead.
Inherent enmity between members of a family.
Feud between two branches of family.
Person reproached for having no relatives.
r: Irish myth: Cross; Koryak: *Jochelson JE VI 372.
N. A. Indian: Kroeber JAFL XXI 225.
a: A boy interrupts a game played with the bones of his father or other murdered relative.

d: Wife chooses father's side in feud.
r: S. A. Indian (Carib): Alexander Lat. Am.
a: Must choose between husband and father.

d: Wife chooses father rather than husband or son.
Mother kills husband for murdering their daughter.
Wife more merciful than blood relations.
a: They refuse to ransom condemned man; wife does so.

d: Husband more merciful than blood relations.
a: They refuse to ransom condemned woman; husband does so.

d: Wife drinks blood of slain husband.
Wife commits suicide (dies) on death of husband.
Wife only one able to persuade her husband.

r: Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 527a s.v. "Eltern und Kinder"; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Mother dislikes her children in forced marriage.
Queen dislikes son who is unlike her and loves a poor girl: plots against him.
Boy sickens from grief at mother's death.

a: (Hamlet.)

d: Mother kills sons who lack courage to help her revenge her father and brothers, and are likely to betray the plot.
Mother reveals fact that son is offspring of supernatural father.
Mother (eagle) casts out dull, stupid changeling; rears bold, energetic son.
Mother commits suicide when son wants to marry foreigner according to foreign rites.
Wicked mother and her sons do everything to prevent daughter's marriage with beloved.
Mother lets daughter unwittingly marry own father in order to avenge his raping.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Son as pledge for father who has committed murder.
Young hero rebuked by his father.
Father drives away bad son whom the mother prefers.
Berserks scold their father who apparently without reason called their adversary invincible.
Hero's son by giantess scorns his father's feebleness: still it is the son who is slain.
Oldest son responsible to father for welfare of others.

r: English romance: Malory X 21, 34, 36; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa: Bouveignes 163.

d: Son must threaten father before he will recognize him as son, even though he brings ring from his mother.
Son chastizes father for scorning mother.
Father in vision reproves son about to succumb to temptation.
Birthright transferred by father from the oldest son to another.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Daughter marries her husband's slayer in order to save her old father from war.
Father and daughter die at same time.
Folly of father's giving all property to children before his death.
r: *Oesterley No. 273; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 980A. Cf. Shakespeare's King Lear.
a: They abandon him.

d: Supposed chest of gold induces children to care for aged father.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 435; Scala Celi 98b No. 528; Dunlop-Wilson II 185f.; von der Hagen II lviii No. 49; Hdwb. d. Abergl. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2452*; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 980A; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Palestine: Schmidt-Kahle Volkserzdhlungen aus Paldstina II No. 123; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Jeynball Catalogus Maleische en Sundaneesche Hss.
a: They think that the chest of stones contains the inheritance.

d: Not daring to curse father directly, son does so indirectly.
Son deposes father and usurps throne.
Undutiful children ridicule father while he is drunk and naked.
Undutiful son overawes his father by threats.
Undutiful son taught lesson showing his mother has suffered from him.
Parents descend to hell instead of sons.
Pious children save their parents from hell.

r: *Penzer III 272 n. 1; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

a: Brought to test by actions at apparent death of hero.

d: Warrior will not fight where his brother was slain.
a: Place considered defiled.

d: Brothers follow each other in exile.
Brothers strive to avenge each other.
Brothers kill brother because they fail to understand his wise answer.
Two brothers follow and help each other on piracy, etc.
Two brothers are confusingly like each other.
Man's descendants shall serve those of his brother.
Older brother has birthright, entitling him to a double share.
Repudiation of relationship of birth between man and his bad brother.

r: Type 450; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: One sister and six (seven, eleven, twelve) brothers.
Brother about to drink blood of seemingly guilty sister.

r: East Africa: Zuure L'Ame du Murundi (Paris, 1932) 331ff.

d: Brother chosen rather than husband or son.
r: Chauvin II 190 No. 2; Tawney Journal of Philology XII 121; Aly Volksmdrchen bei Herodot 35, 109; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 257 No. 31.
a: Only one can be saved; he alone is irreplaceable.

d: Girl comes to brother's aid when he is attacked.
a: She slays the assailant and is eventually acquitted.

d: Brothers persecute sister's lover and are in return killed by him.
Clever sister saves life of brother.
Woman dies of sorrow for death of brother.
Bad relations between mother-in-law and daughter-in-law.
Idle sons-in-law driven away by gradually reducing their food.
Foster parents fined for blemish on child.
Peasant and his wife as foster parents of exposed king's son.
Parents kill son for slaying their foster son.

r: **C. Schubert Der Pflegesohn (Nourri) im Heldenepos (Marburg, 1906); Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire.
(Cf. +N845.) English romance: Malory, Book 1; Icelandic: Boberg.

d: Living king's or nobleman's son as foster son of father's friend: considered an honor for the foster father.
Foster children return foster father's love: avenge him, etc.
King's son named after his father's foster father.
Thor slays his foster father and takes himself the realm of Thrace.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Former mistress as sons' foster mother.

r: *Valtyr Gudmundsson "Fustbrzhdralag" in prjbr Ritgjtsrethir (Kaupmannahtsfn, 1892) 29 55; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.
*Type 516; *BP I 46; *Rtssch FFC LXXVII 96; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.

d: King's son begs pardon for treacherous foster brother.
Promise of marriage to king's daughter induces warrior to fight foster brother.
Earl's son seduces foster brother's sister and betrays himself.
King's son falsely accuses foster brother of attempt to seduce his sister.
Magic writing makes foster brothers enemies.
Unable to hit man himself, enemy kills his foster brother.
Children of Tuatha De Danann fostered by Milesians.
Love between foster sister and foster brother.
Foster son commits adultery with foster father's wife.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Realm ruled by stepmother, while king is absent.
Stepmother mourns her stepsons' death, not her own son's.  Icelandic: Boberg.

r: (Cf. +T418.) Irish myth: Cross; Greek: Euripides Hippolytus; Chinese-Persian: *Coyajee JPASB XXIV 192.

d: Love of stepmother who has killed her husband refused.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Children take after their mother's brothers.
Hero killed in fighting with father's brother.
Young prince sent to his father's mother's brother.

r: *Rivers "The Father's Sister in Oceania" FL XXI 42.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 82.

d: Friends want to divide good and evil.
Dying hero sends greetings to friends.
Friends want their children to be friends too.
Dying man asks friends to let his son inherit his friendship together with his father's weapons.
One friend dies shortly after the other.
Man wins wife for his friend.
Friends given the power of reading each other's secret thoughts.

r: *Type 516; Rtssch FFC LXXVII 98; *Hibbard 68 n. 7, 145 n. 3; Child IV 146f.; Wesselski Mdrchen 187 No. 2; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17; *Abeles "Die Burgschaft als Motif in der j'dischen Literatur" Monatsch. a: Friends take an oath of lasting brotherhood.
Friends take oath of brotherhood by exchanging flowers.

d: Human sons of animal companions go together on adventures Africa.
Saints exchange bachalls as mark of affection.
Friendship between a prince and common man.

r: *Type 1364; **Encyc. Rel. Irish myth: Cross: Icelandic: *Boberg; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G 13/203); Africa: Stanley 274.
a: Friends take oath of brotherhood by means of mixing their blood.

d: Saint makes blood covenant with animals.
Drinking mixture of blood, milk, and wine as pledge of covenant.
Sworn brethren and blood brethren avenge each other.
Surviving blood brother to watch three nights in grave-mound.
r: Icelandic: Egils saga ok Asm., Lagerholm 28 (cf. introd.

a: Friends bound in brotherhood through partaking of milk from the same woman.

d: Friendship starts at babyhood: two babies exchanged.
Friends offer to die for each other.
r: Often combined with +P325. **Abeles "Die B'rgschaft als Motif in der j'dischen Literatur" Monatschr. d. Mdrchens I 350a s.v. "B'rgschaft"; Ktshler-Bolte II 557, 580f.; Gaster Exempla Nos. 362, 419; Basset 1001 Contes II 293ff.; Boccaccio Decameron X No. 8 (*Lee 330); Fischer Zs. f. Vksk. Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: (B'rgschaft.) Each falsely confesses crime so as to save the other. Neither guilty.

d: Competition in friendship: prisoner and jailor.
a: Officer in charge of prison offers to let his friend escape, though his own life will be forfeited. The friend refuses; tells officer to let king think he has escaped and if the king demands his life the officer can produce the prisoner. King hears of the generosity and forgives the prisoner.

d: Friend gives false witness to set free his accused friend.
Friend sacrifices his life for the other.
Man knowing of murder plot against his friend disguises and is killed in his place.
r: (Cf. +P361.1.) Scala Celi 9b No. 61; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Refusal to believe that a friend has spoken ill of one.
Refusal to believe that a friend will harm one.
a: Alexander drinks cup said to have been poisoned by his friend.

d: Man refuses to follow friend in wicked conduct.
r: Scala Celi 11a No. 66; Alphabet No. 56; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Two friends captured by Moors have money to ransom only one.
a: The ransomed one returns home, gets money and buys the other's freedom.

d: Man who has counseled friend in assassination asks to be killed on the other's body.
Friend's intercession saves man from execution.

a: Man is abducted by pirates and kept in slavery forty years. Upon his return his friend divides his earnings with him.

d: Hands of friends extend through sides of tombs and clasp in death.
Successful rival gives his lady to unsuccessful friend.

a: Friends bind themselves each to grant every desire of the other.

d: Danger of one saint voluntarily incurred by another.

a: Relation of host and guest.
Eating a man's salt creates mutual obligation.
Murderer of a man's father takes refuge in his house and is saved by him.

d: Nobleman forces escaping prisoner to accept his hospitality.
a: Intercedes for his pardon.

d: Guest in disguise or under false name.
Refugee entertained in holy place (church, monastery, etc.).
Hosts refrain from telling guest of death in household.
r: Wesselski Archiv Orientblnn II 431; Greek: Euripides Alcestis.
English romance: Malory passim; Icelandic: Boberg.

d: Host treats guest with food and everything possible.
Host surrenders his wife to his guest.
r: (Often joined with +P315.) Chauvin V 136 No. 64; also references to +P315; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: The guest unwittingly falls in love with the wife. The host, on being informed, out of pure generosity repudiates the wife and has her marry the guest.

d: Guest begets son with his host's daughter.
If host does not return, the house shall belong to the guest.
a: So declares the host as he departs on a mission for the guest.

r: *Chauvin V 163 No. 86; Arabian: Burton Nights I 317.
a: Host places imaginary feast before guest, who accepts it in the same spirit. Guest's courtesy is rewarded by real feast.

d: Strangers entertained by family to whose hitching-ring they happen to tie their horses.
r: Italian: L. de Francia Novellino (Torino, 1930), Rotunda.
a: Thus confusion avoided as to where strangers are to be entertained.

d: Refusal to receive preferred help until series of stories has been told.

a: Porcupine asks rabbit for hospitality. When rabbit complains of being pricked, porcupine tells him to leave if he does not like it.

d: Shabby hospitality forces guests to leave.
Poor person makes great effort to entertain guests.
Poor host and his wife kill themselves because they are unable to entertain expected guests.
Wife scolds husband's hospitality, as he really has nothing to give.
Poor peasant closes the eyes in order not to see guest eat: later suicide.
King demands work, sport or entertainment from winter guests.
Christian king makes baptism a condition for hospitality during the winter.
Sitting in a circle of feasts.
Teacher dies of pride over success of pupil.
Student enters competition with his master.

a: Is overcome by the latter's tricks.

d: Teacher threatens to curse pupils if they disobey.

r: *Types 516; *BP I 46; **Rtssch FFC LXXVII 95f.; **Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 389 (and cross references there given); Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 154ff.

d: Faithful servant dies for his master.
a: Puts on his master's clothes so as to be slain in his place.

d: Faithful servant kills his master's murderer and is killed in turn.
Faithful servant wants to follow on dangerous quest, where he alone is killed.
Hero's charioteer faithful to master till death.
Faithful servant remains at home and fights for exiled hero.
Faithful servant sacrifices sons to save life of king.
a: Sons resuscitated and servant enriched.

d: Faithful nurse tries to save tyrant's daughter by exposing her own in her place.
Abandoned maiden helped by her faithful nurse.
Faithful servant dies avenging master's death.
Captain will not betray king's secret.
a: He refuses to betray where recruits are being raised.

d: Faithful servant undergoes torture for sake of his master.
Crow lets itself be caught so as to save king of crows.
Faithful servant entrusted with care and education of crown prince.
Faithless men-servants corrupt the maids in the household.
r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 209; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Servant planning to possess his master's goods.
a: Has already possessed his wife.

d: Master demands that servant tell him of his faults as well as of his good qualities.

r: **Sibillot Ligendes et Curiositis des Mitiers (Paris, n.d.); Jewish: Neuman.

d: Son insists on following father's trade.
a: This has been kept secret at request of dying father who was unsuccessful. Son learns from mother.

d: Peasant refuses to sell possessions to king.
a: (Miller of Sanssouci.)

d: Peasant and his wife in hut near castle as contrasts to king and queen.
Peasant is cutting wood in front of his house as guests arrive.
Wounded hero finds shelter and is cured in peasant's house.
Hero stays overnight in peasant's house, to which he accidentally comes, and where he gets advice and direction.
Life of shepherd proper preparation for ruler.

a: Always transports passengers and when the ruler is in danger takes his place.

d: Ferryman puts oar into king's hand and he must remain ferryman.
Tongue of dead lawyer found to be lacking.
r: Scala Celi 7b No. 44; Etienne de Bourbon No. 440.
Penzer X 263a s.v. "Physician"; Irish myth: Cross.

d: Physician hides eyes as he passes graveyard.
a: He does not want to see those who have died from his medicine.

d: Doctor who can cure can also poison.
a: This reflection brings the doctor under the king's suspicion.

d: "Skillful" physician compelled to help carry away the bier of his dead patient.
Scribe who cannot read his own writing.
In fear of clerics pagans flee into fairy mounds.
First of animals and fruits belong to priest.

r: Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 507b; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish: Espinosa II No. 75, Espinosa Jr.

d: Untrained monk becomes skillful wright (smith) through power of saint.
Woman disguised as monk enters monastery.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 311.

d: Druid inspires great respect and fear.
Person assailed by druid loses treasure.
Fear of druidic lampoon as activating power.
Wounded soldiers healed by bath in pool of milk through power of druid.
Wealthy usurer prays that the sons of the rich will become mad.
a: That will benefit his business. His own sons lose their minds.
He does so, not because it is wrong, but because he is losing money.

r: *Fb "skrzhdder"; *Chauvin IX 29 No. 18; *Sibillot Mitiers No. 7; *Feilberg Dania I 165ff., III 184ff.; Paludan Danske Studier (1925) 19ff.; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Tailor occupies God's throne for a day.
Tailoring only trade devil cannot learn.
a: He fails to knot thread because it would make sign of the cross.

d: Busy tailor asks soldier to mount watch in his place.

r: Type 461 (Danish); Von Sydow Vera folksagor (1941) 38; *Sibillot Mitiers No. 1; Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish: Espinosa Jr.

d: Brave soldier and timid cabinet-maker as companions.
Why weavers are the most unhappy of men.
a: They gave a nail for the Crucifixion.

r: Sibillot Mitiers No. 11; Penzer III 100 n. 1.

*Sibillot Mitiers Nos. 17, 18; *Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachtrdge 257 67; Andree (1878) 153; *Nyrop Dania IX 186ff.; Von Sydow Vera folksagor (1941) 39ff. Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Missouri French: Carriire; Jewish: *Neuman.

d: Smith as lord of hall of hospitality.
Smith honored by king as indispensable.
a: Invited to festival.

r: Type 326; German Grimm No. 4; *Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachtrdge 269f.; Sibillot Mitiers No. 8.

a: A shoemaker spits at Christ on way to be crucified. Christ tells him, "A poor slobbering fellow thou shalt be, and all shoemakers after thee, for what thou has done to me."

r: Types 327, 700; Ktshler Aufsdtze 49; Sibillot Mitiers No. 16; Missouri French: Carriire.
*Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachtrdge 485ff.; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Soldier who has had both hands severed fights with his teeth until he is killed.
Soldier dies happy on learning of enemy's rout.
Soldier is ordered to set fire to enemy's armada.
a: Is caught and sawed in two.

d: Woman instructs in art of arms.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire; Jewish: *Neuman.
Penzer X 77a s.v. "Astrologer"; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.
*E. v. K'nssberg Rechtliche Volkskunde (Halle, 1936); **Spargo Juridicial Folklore in England (Durham N.C., 1944); Irish myth: Cross.

d: Criminal allowed to choose his method of execution.
Chooses to die of old age.
r: (Cf. +J1181.) Hdwb. d. Mdrchens s.v. "Friedrich der Grosse" n. 58.
a: Criminal given choice of deaths.

d: Man condemned to lose his eye is allowed to choose the instrument.
r: Herbert III 71; Hervieux IV 310 No. 117; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Condemned woman may be freed by marrying a rogue.
Release from execution at a woman's request (by marriage to her).
Criminal may fight against odds rather than be judicially executed.
Pardoning of criminal comes too late.
Youngest of judges first to give decision.
Crime less serious if committed at request of a lady.

a: He has put the criminal to torture without success. When he releases him, the criminal says, "In a moment I should have confessed all." The judge lets him go nevertheless.

r: (Cf. +P535.) Irish myth: Cross (+P548.2); India: Thompson-Balys; New Guinea: Ker 61.
a: One life for one life. Equal number must be given up by each feuding side.

d: Fool not to be punished for his crime.
Poet may not act as security.
Foreigner may not act as security.
"It is a debt if it is promised."
Contract made by woman without her husband void.
He nearest to blood of slain man must avenge his death.
"To every cow belongs its calf,"  a legal principle applied to question of ownership of copy of manuscript.
"To every son belongs his mother" : in case of suspected illegitimacy, child is not guilty.
Taxation and payment of fines or tribute.
Tribe failing to attend yearly feast to send gift as sign of submission.

a: Specified interchange of aid and gifts.

d: Eric fines (imposed for personal injury, etc.).
Punishment for failure to pay tax.
Nose cut off for failure to pay tax.

a: Laws made in groups of seven.

d: Laws made at feast every seven years.

r: *Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachtrdge 181 254; Jewish: Neuman.

a: Old men excluded.

d: Soldiers chained (tied) together to prevent flight from battle.
Hero drives retreating warriors back into battle.
Law requiring military service of women revoked through influence of saint.
Retainers not required to go to battle under overlord except for pay.
Only 700 subjects of under-king required to serve under overlord on any one hosting.

a: Warriors fight in circle around leader.

d: Superior troops distributed throughout army to prevent their soldierly qualities from being too obvious.

a: Testudo.
Losses reckoned by number of stones remaining in pile after each survivor has removed one.

d: Submission indicated by defeated lying with conqueror's sword between teeth.
Heads of fallen enemies piled up after battle.

a: Heads of slain enemies displayed.

d: Gate of captured town (castle) to be widened until overlord's spear can pass through crosswise.
Challenge by turning left side of shield toward enemy.
Challenge to battle by hurling javelin skyward.
Warrior not entitled to ransom if captured without arms.
Pledge with enemy to be kept.
First to reach field of combat has choice of weapons.
Warrior who begins combat has right to desist.
Choice of weapons alternates each succeeding day.

a: Challenger to single combat must submit to same conditions as person challenged.

d: Warrior engaged in combat with one-armed opponent allows one hand to be bound to his side.
Warrior disgraced by slaying of those under his protection.
Warrior dies with face toward foe.
Divorce given to wives before leaving for battle.

r: **R. C. Clephan The Tournament (London, 1919); *O. Mueller Turnier und Kampf in den altfrz.

d: King is persuaded to rescind ban on tournaments.
Tournament: to avenge death of king.
Trumpet blown before house of one sentenced to death.
Charon's fee: putting coin in dead person's mouth to pay for ferry across Styx.
Newcomers forced to pass the night with ruling princess.
a: Given sleeping potion. Goods confiscated for failure to consummate marriage.

d: People weep when child is born.
a: They sing and laugh at burials.

d: Bridle goes with horse when horse is bought.
Servant must keep horns and hide of his cattle that are slain.
Clerics fast against God for revelation.
Fasting by saints causes tree worshipped by pagans to fall.
Calves not let to cows during fast.
Strangers to be given precedence over man at home.
a: Duke permits visiting duke to go through narrow path first. This sets custom.

d: Couches provided for men of high rank.
Cuts of meat distributed according to rank.

a: The choicest portion assigned to the bravest at feasts.

d: Rank among children recognized by quality of appointments and food.
Precedence shown by position of shield (flag).
Long hair prized by Irish heroes.
Customs connected with eating and food.
Feast (hospitality) endures for three days and three nights.
Feast (hospitality) endures for seven days and seven nights.
Injured husband will not kill a naked man.
Only the brave to wear beards.

a: Hero goes to encounter unarmed except for the arms he wrests from his opponent.

d: Hero unwilling to answer questions before he is dressed.
Bells hung at every corner of ship.
Hut for invalid to prevent noxious odor.
Woman veils self as expression of surprise.
Pulling a man's beard as an insult.
r: E. Hinojosa Homenaje a Menindez y Pelayo I 568ff.; R. Menindez Pidal Cantar del Mio Cid II 498; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Fur made of beards of conquered kings.
Cutting off a man's (woman's) hair as an insult.
Rubbing shaved head of hero with cow dung as insult.
Insult: lighting lamp with king's moustache.
Old person commits suicide when strength fails.
Touching head as sign of acceptance of bargain.

r: Greek: Iliad XXII 337 and passim; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Duel: shooting and catching arrows in turn.
Pulling out hair as sign of grief.
Tearing garments as sign of grief.
Voyagers have right to ask landsman first question.

r: Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Wolves of his own country dearer than dogs of another.
Mother of invalided soldier says of his limping: "Every step will remind you of your virtue."
Common citizen saves the honor of his country.
a: Gives his own funds.

d: Scipio plunges into burning pit to save Rome from destruction.

a: Kills another by mistake. Burns off his hand for having failed.

d: National unity preserved by expulsion of all foreign elements.
Aristotle rises from sick bed to rush into battle for his country.
Aversion to burial in foreign soil.
Patriotism: king learning that nation will triumph whose king dies in battle, allows self to be killed.
